sub_topic: Solving nonlinear equations using Newton-Raphson method
message_1: Suppose you are given the equation f(x) = x^3 - 2x -5. Use the Newton-Raphson method to find the root of the equation correct to 3 decimal places, starting with an initial guess of x0 = 2.
message_2:
To use the Newton-Raphson method, we first need to find the derivative of the given function, f(x) = x^3 - 2x - 5. 

The derivative, f'(x), is given by:
f'(x) = 3x^2 - 2

Now, we will apply the Newton-Raphson formula iteratively until we reach the desired accuracy of 3 decimal places. The formula is:

x1 = x0 - f(x0) / f'(x0)

We start with the initial guess x0 = 2.

Iteration 1:
x1 = 2 - ( (2^3 - 2*2 - 5) / (3*(2^2) - 2) )
x1 = 2 - ( (8 - 4 - 5) / (12 - 2) )
x1 = 2 - ( -1 / 10 )
x1 = 2 + 0.1
x1 = 2.1

Iteration 2:
x2 = x1 - f(x1) / f'(x1)
x2 = 2.1 - ( (2.1^3 - 2*2.1 - 5) / (3*(2.1^2) - 2) )
x2 ≈ 2.094

Iteration 3:
x3 = x2 - f(x2) / f'(x2)
x3 = 2.094 - ( (2.094^3 - 2*2.094 - 5) / (3*(2.094^2) - 2) )
x3 ≈ 2.0946

We can stop here since the result is accurate to 3 decimal places (2.095). Therefore, the root of the equation f(x) = x^3 - 2x - 5 using the Newton-Raphson method with an initial guess of x0 = 2 is approximately 2.095.
